intro: Eurystegia corydalis, commonly known as the golden bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It features showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from yellow to orange, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. The plant has lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy texture and grows to a height of about 30 to 60 centimeters. It prefers well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade, making it a suitable candidate for rock gardens or alpine settings. Its botanical significance lies in its ornamental value and its role in local ecosystems.
